historyLebanon.title: History of Lebanon
historyLebanon.text: Discover Lebanon's historical journey from its establishment through independence to liberation

content.title: Emergence of the Entity
content.text:
"Greater Lebanon" born on September 1, 1920, had been gestating in the womb of the Levant for many years. Its features appeared during the Ottoman period as "Mount Lebanon" or "Little Lebanon". French General Gouraud declared the establishment of Lebanon with its current borders after severing it from Syria, following the Ottoman defeat in World War I.

Lebanon immediately fell under French Mandate during the European colonial division of the Arab East. The Lebanese sought both independence and a clear national identity during this period, issues that continue to impact Lebanon's political reality today.

content.title: Independence
content.text: Lebanon gained formal independence on November 22, 1943, through political struggle against the French, coinciding with WWII geopolitical changes. The National Pact established a sectarian power-sharing system between Lebanon's different communities.

content.title: Civil War
content.text: Accumulated tensions exploded into a 15-year civil war (1975-1990), officially ending with the Taif Agreement. While sectarian on surface, the war carried regional dimensions intertwined with the Arab-Israeli conflict. Israel invaded Lebanon up to the Litani River in 1978 during the war.

content.title: Israeli Invasion
content.text: On June 6, 1982, Israeli forces invaded Lebanon reaching Beirut, aiming to eliminate Palestinian resistance. This invasion sparked the Islamic Resistance in Lebanon (Hezbollah), building on resistance foundations laid by Imam Musa Sadr's Amal Movement in the 1970s.

content.title: Second Birth
content.text: The 1989 Taif Agreement ended the civil war and restructured Lebanon's political system under Syrian guardianship. This relative stability lasted until Syria's 2005 withdrawal following Prime Minister Rafik Hariri's assassination.

content.title: Liberation War
content.text: The Islamic Resistance's operations culminated in liberating south Lebanon on May 25, 2000. Israel's 2006 "July War" failed to destroy the resistance, ending in divine victory after 33 days. Parts of Lebanese territory remain occupied in Shebaa Farms and Kfar Shuba hills.

content.title: Doha Agreement
content.text: The 2008 Doha Agreement prevented civil war after political tensions following Hariri's assassination, reaffirming national unity against sectarian strife.

content.title: Syria War Impact
content.text: The Syrian war brought new security challenges. The resistance protected border areas, culminating in 2017's liberation of Arsal outskirts through joint operations with Lebanese and Syrian armies.

content.title: Economic Crisis & October 17 Uprising
content.text: Long-term economic mismanagement exploded in nationwide protests starting October 17, 2019, triggering currency collapse and ongoing crises.

historyResistance.title: History of the Resistance
historyResistance.text: Explore the Lebanese resistance's journey from inception to liberation victories

content.title: Foundation: 1982 Israeli Invasion
content.text: The 1982 invasion birthed the Islamic Resistance to counter Israeli occupation, emerging from popular will to defend Lebanese sovereignty.

content.title: 1985: First Withdrawal to Border Zone
content.text: After fierce resistance forced Israeli withdrawal to a "security zone", resistance operations intensified against remaining occupation forces.

content.title: 1993: Operation Accountability
content.text: Israel's brutal 1993 aggression failed to break resistance resolve, proving invincibility against popular will.

content.title: 1996: Qana Massacre & Turning Point
content.text: The 1996 "Grapes of Wrath" offensive and Qana massacre led to the April Understanding, legitimizing resistance defense rights.

content.title: May 2000 Liberation: Divine Victory
content.text: Israel's chaotic May 2000 withdrawal marked historic victory, proving occupation's impermanence through divine promise.

content.title: July 2006 War: Shattering Invincibility Myth
content.text: 33-day war saw innovative resistance tactics destroy Israel's military prestige through strategic strikes and ground defense.

content.title: 2017 Second Liberation: Defeating Takfiri Terror
content.text: Joint military operations cleared ISIS from eastern border regions, affirming "Army-People-Resistance" formula.

content.title: Al-Aqsa Flood Operation
content.text: October 7, 2023's unprecedented operation breached Israeli defenses, reshaping regional conflict dynamics.

content.title: Support Front for Gaza
content.text: Lebanese resistance opened northern front in Gaza war, forcing multi-front combat unprecedented in Israeli history.

content.title: Battle of the Valiant
content.text: 2023-2024 battles saw heroic defense of border villages, ending with UNSC 1701 reaffirmation for full Israeli withdrawal.

content.title: Getting a SIM Card
content.text: Two mobile providers: touch & alfa. SIM cards cost $10-20 at authorized sellers. Check company websites for plans.

content.title: Transportation
content.text:
Public transport includes:
Buses: Fixed routes, LBP 100-150k fare
Taxis: Shared rides, LBP 200-250k per passenger
Ride-hailing: Uber/Bolt with distance-based fares

content.title: Currencies
content.text:
Lebanese pounds and USD accepted everywhere. Exchange rates:
USD: 1 = LBP 90,000
EUR: 1 = LBP 94,000
IQD 1,000 = LBP 68,000
IRR 1,000 = LBP 21,000

map.title: Map
map.text: Explore Lebanon's geography, cities, and landmarks

content.title: Geographic Location
content.text: Lebanon borders Mediterranean Sea, Syria, and occupied Palestine. 10,452 kmÂ² area with coastal, mountainous, and plain regions. Beirut is the coastal capital.

content.title: Governorates
content.text: 8 governorates: Beirut, Mount Lebanon, Akkar, North, Baalbek-Hermel, Bekaa, South, Nabatieh. Divided into districts and municipalities.

content.title: Climate & Terrain
content.text: Mediterranean climate with four seasons. Summer beach tourism, winter skiing in mountain resorts.

content.title: Major Cities
content.text: Beirut, Tripoli (North), Sidon (South) - each with unique cultural heritage.

content.title: Historic Sites
content.text: Baalbek Roman temples, Byblos ancient port, Tyre Phoenician ruins, Crusader castles.

content.title: Natural Areas
content.text: Cedars forests, Qadisha Valley, Faraya ski resorts - year-round tourism destinations.

content.title: Coastal Regions
content.text: Mediterranean coastline with beaches and resorts, historic ports in coastal cities.

content.title: Agricultural Zones
content.text: Fertile Bekaa Valley as Lebanon's food basket, famous for vineyards and produce.
